STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 26, 2021
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
RE: License #: CB380201255
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility inspection completed on
8/9/21. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract, and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations
describe why the previous CAP was unsuccessful and what changes will
be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of six foster home files held documentation that the application was provided at
55 days prior to license expiration and therefore did not meet this requirement.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
One of six foster home files held a temporary (1 year) approval of their
environmental health inspection from 11/12/19. No follow-up approval was on file.
The annual revaluation for 2021 did not address how this issue was corrected or
verify compliance during the current year. The agency was advised to consult the
Technical Assistance manual in the future about how to address this situation as it
is uncommon.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
One of three borrowed bed files did not have documentation that the foster parent
was willing to accept placement, prior to placement occurring.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
4

One of three borrowed bed files held an initial evaluation that was not endorsed by
the agency.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of three borrowed bed files held a renewal evaluation that was not endorsed by
the agency.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
Two of three borrowed bed files did not have documentation that orientation was
completed prior to placement.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed bed files did not have a signed foster parent/agency
agreement.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
5

One of three special evaluations did not have documentation the report was
provided to the foster parent. The agency stated the report was sent via mail, but
the agency did not document the mailing.
R 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with
the terms of the contract required by R 400.12510, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable environmental, and is managing
expenditures.
One of three independent living files did not have budgets for May or June 2021.
R 500.12507 Medical/dental and mental health
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
One of three independent living files did not have a medical on file as required. The
youth’s last medical was 3/2/20. A new medical was due by May 2021.
R 400.12422 Foster care record
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information: (g) A
photograph taken at least annually.
One of three independent living files did not have an annually update photo. The
last photo on file was from 3/31/20.
One of six foster care files did not have an annually updated photo. The last photo
on file was from 7/1/20.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following: (f) The provision of a
dental examination and any treatment required for each child
who is 4 years of age and older, including both of the
following…
6

Two of six foster care files did not have dental exams as required.
File one: MiSACWIS indicated dental exams on 1/24/20, 7/31/20 and 9/9/20.
However, there was no documentation to accompany these dates.
File two: The youth entered care on 6/1/20. No dental exam was on file.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following: (b) An
agency social service worker shall visit the foster child and the
foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once every
month.
Three of six foster care files were missing documentation of monthly foster home
visits.
File one: Did not have documentation of a FHV in January 2021
File two: Did not have documentation of a FHV for January or February 2021.
File three: Did not have documentation of a FHV for January or February 2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following: (a) A plan
of visitation for each child in foster care consistent with the
child’s service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to assure the safety and well-being of the child.
Three of six foster care files did not have documentation of parenting time as
required.
File one: Parenting time was not documented for October or November 2020.
File two: Parenting time was not documented from 3/8/20 to present. The PATP
indicated that visits were planned for two hours, weekly. However, no contact dates
were entered to confirm these visits occurred.
File three: Parenting time was not documented for January-March 2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following: (d)
Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits
are detrimental to either child.
7

One of six foster care files did not meet this requirement. Only one sibling visit was
documented from January to June 2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows: (b) Within 120 calendar days
after the initial removal and at least once every 90 calendar
days thereafter.
Two of six foster care files held late or missing USPs.
File one: USP due 2/21/21, was not completed until 6/15/21. USP due 5/22/21 was
not completed until 7/1/21.
File two: USP dated as 4/14/21 is “in progress” and not complete. USP due 7/14/21
was not completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
9/4/19 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/19/19
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An Agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child…
Two of six foster care files did not have documentation to verify compliance with
this rule.
File one: The youth moved on 8/4/20 and 4/20/21. Placement outlines were not
completed to document the required information was shared with the new FH.
File two: The youth moved on 7/30/20 and 1/7/21. Placement outlines were not
completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
8

FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change.
Three of three independent living files did not have DHHS-69 Action Summary
forms completed as required.
File one: The case closed on 2/11/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed.
File two: The case closed on 5/14/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed.
File three: The case closed on 5/20/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed
Three of six foster care files did not have a DHHS-69 completed as required.
File one: The youth moved on 8/4/20 and 4/20/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed.
File two: The youth returned home on 3/25/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed.
File three: A caseworker change occurred on 7/1/21; a DHHS-69 was on file but it
was incomplete and did not have signatures. In addition, the youth moved on
7/30/20, 1/7/21 and 6/18/21; a DHHS-69 was not completed.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
The caseworker must meet with his/her supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case.
One IL and six foster care files did not have supervision documented as required.
File one: (IL) Supervision was not documented for May or June 2021.
File two & three: Supervision was not documented for September and October
2020.
File four: Supervision was not documented for July, August, September, October,
and December 2020; January and February 2021.
File five: Supervision was not documented for July, September, October,
November, and December 2020; January, February, and April 2021.
File six: Supervision was not documented for September, October, November, and
December 2020; January, February, April, and May 2021.
File seven: Supervision was not documented for July, August, September, October,
November, and December 2020; January, February, April, and May 2021.
FOM 722-08c Foster Care- Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Page 9 Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
9

case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
CI 17-099
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from all
appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and older for
foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile justice, should
be obtained before the corresponding court hearing. All treatment
plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later must have
signatures from all appropriate case members within 30 days of
the report date.
Six of six foster care files held a total of nineteen PATPs with signatures that were
missing or not completed within 30 days.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 18
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
One independent living file and three foster care files held case contacts that were
not entered within five business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
9/4/19 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/19/19
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Page 2
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents,
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement,
quarterly.
• Older youth/young adults upon initial IL placement, upon
exiting the foster care system, YAVFC youth
10

Six of six foster care files did not have medical passports as required.
File one: Medical Passports were not updated quarterly. Only two were on file for
the past year. In addition, a passport was not completed for a 4/20/21 move.
File two: No medical passports on file.
File three: One medical passport was on file for the past year. There was no
indication the passport was sent to the parent.
File four and five: Passports were not updated on a quarterly basis.
File six: Passports were not updated on a quarterly basis. A passport was not
updated for the youth’s moves on 1/7/21 or 6/18/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
9/4/19 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/19/19
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 5
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following…
Six of six foster care files did not have FTMs completed as required.
File one: Three USPs did not have corresponding FTMs. Placement changes on
8/4/20 and 4/20/21 did not have required FTMs.
File two: Three USPs did not have corresponding FTMs.
File three: Three USPs did not have corresponding FTMs.
File four: Three USPs did not have corresponding FTMs.
File five: Three USPs did not have corresponding FTMs.
File six: One USP did not have a corresponding FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
9/4/19 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/19/19
FOM 722-03D Placement Change
Page 8
Any time placement is made the following documents must be
provided to the new caregiver at or before the time of
placement: Medical Information. DHS-3762, Consent to
Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care and Emergency
Medical/Surgical Treatment Card.
Two of six foster care files did not have documentation that the DHS-3762 was
provided to the foster parents at placement. Both case files had two moves in
which this was not completed.
11

FOM 722-06H Quality FHV
Page 3
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting (which
includes safe sleep verification) occurred for each child
participant in the Participant screen within the Social Work
Contact section of MiSACWIS.
Two of six foster care files each held one foster home visit in which there was
insufficient documentation of a quality FHV.
REPEAT VIOLATION
6/3/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
9/4/19 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/19/19
FOM 722-03D Placement change
Page 4
The caregiver must be notified of the intent to move the child 14
days prior to the intended date of the move unless the child’s
health and safety is jeopardized. The DHS-30, Foster Parent
Notification of Move, must be used to notify the caregiver of the
intent to move the child.
The DHS-30 also contains information for the caregiver
regarding whether the right to appeal the placement change
exists based on the placement change reason and instructions
for exercising their right to appeal; see Caregiver Appeal to the
Foster Care Review Board in this item.
The DHS-30 must be uploaded to MiSACWIS in the document
hyperlink in the child's placement record.
One of six foster care files did not have a DHHS-30 completed for moves that
occurred on 6/18/20 and 1/7/21.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 9
The primary foster care caseworker must have face-to-face
contact with the parent/legal guardian at least once per calendar
month. At least one contact each quarter must occur in the
parent’s residence.
Two of six foster care files did not have documentation of quarterly visits occurring
in the parental home as required.
File one: Did not have a parental home visit from September 2020 to March 2021.
File two: Did not have a parental home visit in 2020, and only one visit in 2021.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Page 1 Agreement
12

Parental participation is required in developing the
parent/caretaker goals and objectives. The foster care worker
must engage incarcerated parents in the development of the
PATP. This can be achieved through face-to-face, telephone, or
letter contact.
One of six foster care files did not have documentation of PATPs being sent to an
incarcerated parent as required.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 11
Face-to-face contact with parents who are incarcerated,
hospitalized, or participating in an inpatient treatment program is
encouraged but not required. The caseworker must maintain
monthly telephone or written contact with the parent. All
contacts must be documented in MiSACWIS and all written
correspondence must be uploaded in MiSACWIS.
One of six foster care files did not have documentation of contacts with an
incarcerated parent as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Family Team Meetings- Several FTM 1105 reports were found to have names
listed on the signature page, without a signature or indication if the person
attended in person, or via teleconference or videoconference. The agency
was advised to clarify on the 1105 report how participants attend.
 Service Plans- Some foster care files indicated completed USP reports.
However, the report was not saved or “generated” to allow DCWL to open the
file for review. The agency was reminded to save generated reports, to allow
others to view the document in MiSACWIS.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 11/30/20 determined the foster parent medically
neglected a child in her home and did not provide adequate supervision. The foster
parent was substantiated for abuse and neglect and the license was recommended
for revocation. The agency’s findings and recommendation were found to be
appropriate, based on the information gathered during the investigation.
13

There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 3/18/21 determined the foster parents were utilizing
spanking as discipline. The family was found to be in violation of licensing rules and
agency policy. A Corrective Action Plan was implemented and the family is now
back in compliance. The agency’s investigation of this matter and the approved CAP
were reviewed and found to be appropriate.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2021C0207011 was initiated on 3/10/21 regarding notification of a child death in
an unlicensed relative home. The investigation determined the agency followed
protocols for child death notification. However, violations were determined for rules
417(1) foster parent information, 418(2) development of service plans, and contract
requirements for a relative home study. A CAP was approved on 5/25/21 and
continues to be implemented at this time.
SIR 2021C0103026 was initiated on 6/4/21 due to allegations of a lack of
reunification services, late service plans, and missing medical exams. The
investigation determined violations of rules 206(2) staff qualifications, 418(2a)
development of service plans, 413(1c) medical and dental policy, and contract
requirements regarding case planning, contacts, service plan approval, treatment
plan signatures, family team meetings, and medical passports. A CAP was approved
on 8/23/21 and continues to be implemented at this time.
The findings of these two investigations are consistent with the violations found
during this renewal evaluation. The special evaluation CAPs and interim CAP will be
reviewed for compliance during the next inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during this
review period. The Chief Administrator stated the previous year CAP was effective
and there are good systems in place, but the increased staff turnover during the past
year has been disruptive. Also, some staff have struggled with COVID-19
procedures and working remotely without the typical face to face contact and
support from peers and supervisors. In addition, hiring has been a struggle due to a
lack of qualified applicants, leading to positions not being filled timely.
The CA indicated that training and support for staff and supervisors will be increased
to aid in staff retention and fine-tuning job duties. In addition, the agency is
implementing protected time for staff, increased review of Infoview reports by
supervisors, and frequent evaluation of worker’s use of protected time to manage
their cases effectively and provide support as needed. The CA expressed
confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
14

Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff on-site, as well as the program manager
and a supervisor via video conference. Staff acknowledged this year has been
difficulty due to COVID-19 and staffing issues. However, they continue to adjust and
anticipate improvement in many areas over the next several months. Staff reported
feeling supported by supervisors and reported no areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue
on a regular license.
August 25, 2021
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 26, 2021
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
15
